Award.AwardTitle: Western Algebraic Geometry Seminar - Five Year Plan
Award.AbstractNarration:
Western Algebraic Geometry Seminar (WAGS) is a weekend conference on algebraic geometry held twice a year at various institutions in the western region of the United States and Canada, including Utah, Stanford , British Columbia, Berkeley, Colorado State, Washington and now Colorado and Arizona. WAGS has been instrumental in building a vibrant algebraic geometry community in the West. It provides an important way for researchers to connect to one another in the broader geographical area. A crucial feature of WAGS is that it provides an opportunity for algebraic geometers to come together and hear a semesters worth of seminars. Young researchers and graduate students get the opportunity to meet senior faculty, and to get a broader sense of the ﬁeld. The relevance of WAGS in the development of research in algebraic geometry is underscored by the fact that many people around the world currently leading the ﬁeld of algebraic geometry have come up through the WAGS system.

Algebraic geometry concerns the solution sets of algebraic equations, and has long been a central subject in mathematics with deep and substantial connections to almost every aspect of modern mathematics. Beyond the natural interactions with ?neighboring? mathematical ﬁelds such as number theory, symplectic geometry, topology, and commutative algebra, exciting connections have recently emerged between algebraic geometry and apparently ?foreign? fields including mathematical physics, biology, digital communications, and robotics. There are numerous diﬀerent approaches to the study of algebraic geometry, utilizing a wide variety of technical tools; commutative algebra, complex analysis, sheaf theory, cohomological methods, and combinatorial techniques all play important roles. The speakers at WAGS are chosen to represent a broad spectrum of research in the field and a good mix of established figures and young active researchers. A goal of WAGS is certainly to share new research result within algebraic geometry community and to encourage new connections and research collaborations.

Addendum # 1

WAGS is a regional conference in algebraic geometry which meets twice a year in various institutions in the West  (defined for our purposes as the western two time zones of the contiguous 48 states). It has run since 2002, and since 2009 it has been supported by two NSF conference grants. In the last funding cycle, WAGS has met at University of British Columbia, University of Arizona, Stanford, Colorado State, University of Washington, University of Utah, Harvey Mudd College,UCSD, University of Colorado, University of Idaho, UC Davis and again at University of Washington. The participation to each conference is between 50 and 100 mathematicians. There is a large participation of graduate students and junior researchers. Our registration records, which are unfortunately somewhat less than complete (as many senior participants not requesting funding neglect to register), show a total of $795$  participants, out of which $580$ were supported through the NSF conference grant.
WAGS has been instrumental in building a vibrant algebraic geometry community in the West.    Some of the current organizers were  graduate students in the initial years of WAGS, and found it an important way to connect to peers and senior researchers in the broader geographical area.  Many people around the world currently leading the field of algebraic geometry have come up through the WAGS system. Important collaborations, such as the one between Christopher Hacon and James McKernan found origin in contacts had during WAGS conferences. Aaron Bertram heard about Bridgeland Stability Conditions at WAGS - and that inspired much of his subsequent research activity.
WAGS speakers are conducting excellent up-to-date research, and represent a broad spectrum in the field of algebraic geometry.  Special effort is made to invite young researchers who are new to the Western region, so as to actively involve them in the algebraic geometry community.
There are at this point quite a few regular regional conferences in Algebraic Geometry throughout the US; WAGS stands out as it reaches and connects the broadest and least densely populated geographical area.  The geographical distance between the research institutions in the western United States means that many algebraic geometers in the WAGS area are relatively isolated.  A crucial feature of WAGS is that it provides an opportunity for them to come together and hear a semester’s worth of seminars, and equally importantly, meet at length with each other and with younger researchers.   Graduate students get the opportunity to meet senior faculty, and to get a broader sense of the field than they would get from what is represented in their school.
WAGS has been committed to encouraging the participation of members of under-represented groups in mathematics, including women, minorities, and young researchers. Local organizers always make a point of inviting speakers from under-represented groups. 
In conclusion over the last funding cycle WAGS has been an exceptional asset, both for established researchers and for junior persons entering the field. It has allowed algebraic geometry in the Western US to flourish and helped young people develop into professionals. The funding from NSF was instrumental to allow WAGS to support a large number of junior participants and otherwise unfunded researchers.
